title: Explore VCF variants, GWAS snps, promoters and histone marks around the  MEF2C gene in Alzheimers Disease
text: igvR package provides easy programmic access R web-based javascript library igv.js order create display genome tracks richly interactive web browser visual interface. grateful Jim Robinson, Douglass Turner colleagues fine work. introduce igvR via case study genetic variants associated Alzheimer’s Disease described 2014 Nature Genetics paper       Meta-analysis 74,046 individuals identifies 11 new susceptibility loci Alzheimer’s disease1 Theses 11 loci bring total susceptibility loci count 20, MEF2C one. focus 1 megabase region surrounding MEF2C gene contains 208 variants whose presence associated expression MEF2C 17,008 Alzheimer’s disease cases 37,154 controls. Interestingly, variants occur coding regions gene. possible insight function – highly speculative preliminary sort - provided case study. pursue question: non-coding variants alter MEF2C gene regulation disrupting transcription factor binding sites? proceed follows: load igvR package connect igv.js genome browser set reference genome (hg19) zoom MEF2C region expand display entire 1MB region interest create first track - 208 SNPs - using primitive approach: base R data.frame employ Bioconductor’s AnnotationHub retrieve three methylation datasets - associated open chromatin transcription factor binding sites. datasets create igvR track approriate type - igvR’s Track class variety subclasses depending data type data source location. Annotation, Quantitative Variant tracks supported first (1.0) version igvR. good measure conclude loading small slice different variant dataset, VCF format, another Alzheimer’s study 818 participants. VCF files typically contain fine-grained variant data, seen igv.js popup dialog. result running code :  Create igvR instance, default parameters (portRange, quiet, title). Javascript HTML loaded browser, igv.js initialized, websocket connection R process web page constructed, subsequent commands data travel. Display MEF2C
code: library(igvR) library(MotifDb) library(BSgenome.Hsapiens.UCSC.hg19) library(VariantAnnotation) library(AnnotationHub) igv <- igvR() setBrowserWindowTitle(igv, "MEF2C") setGenome(igv, "hg19") showGenomicRegion(igv, "MEF2C")

title: Explore VCF variants, GWAS snps, promoters and histone marks around the  MEF2C gene in Alzheimers Disease
text: next steps expose nuts bolts creating displaying tracks tabular data. None power convenience Biocondcutor AnnotationHub, rtracklayer GenomicRanges used - comes later vignette. Add IGAP GWAS track twice, first annotation track, names avaialble clicking, quantitative track, using -log10(pValue) score, conveying strength association SNP expression target gene, MEF2C, height SNP’s track element. IGAP, International Genomics Alzheimer’s Project, provide data. See Meta-analysis 74,046 individuals identifies 11 new susceptibility loci Alzheimer’s disease, Nature Genetics, Dec 2013.
code: loc <- getGenomicRegion(igv) margin <- 25000 bigger.loc <- with(loc, sprintf("%s:%d-%d", chrom, start-margin, end+margin)) mef2c.region <- with(loc, GRanges(seqnames=chrom, IRanges(start=start+margin, end=end+margin))) showGenomicRegion(igv, bigger.loc) load(system.file(package="igvR", "extdata", "tbl.mef2cGWAS.variants.RData")) tbl.mef2cGWAS.variants.bed <- tbl.mef2cGWAS.variants[, c("CHR", "oldPos", "oldPos", "SNP", "P")] tbl.mef2cGWAS.variants.bed$P <- -log10(tbl.mef2cGWAS.variants.bed$P) colnames(tbl.mef2cGWAS.variants.bed) <- c("chrom", "start", "end", "name", "score") track.gwas <- DataFrameAnnotationTrack("IGAP.gwas", tbl.mef2cGWAS.variants.bed, trackHeight=20, color="darkBlue") displayTrack(igv, track.gwas)  tbl.mef2cGWAS.variants.bedGraph <-  tbl.mef2cGWAS.variants.bed[, -4] track.gwas.numeric <- DataFrameQuantitativeTrack("IGAP.gwas.scored", tbl.mef2cGWAS.variants.bedGraph, autoscale=TRUE) displayTrack(igv, track.gwas.numeric)

what: Use the bioc AnnotationHub to create a promoter track
title: Explore VCF variants, GWAS snps, promoters and histone marks around the  MEF2C gene in Alzheimers Disease
text: location-calculation used identify gene promoters, rather nuanced experimental data, seem later vignette. use default, conservative parameters (2kb upstream TSS, 200bp downstream).
code: ah <- AnnotationHub() ah.human <- subset(ah, species == "Homo sapiens") #---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- # add refseq promoters, available from RefSeq for each transcript which has been identified #---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ah.human.refseq <- query(ah.human, "RefSeq", "hg19", "RefSeq Genes")  # download the first set human.refseq <- ah.human.refseq[[1]] gr.promoters <- promoters(human.refseq, upstream=2000, downstream=200)   # get rid of score, itemRgb, thick, blocks columns in the mcols, keeping just the transcript name.   # these attributes are meaningful for transcript tracks since those include the represenation   # of UTRs, introns and exons.   but a promoter is a stretch of DNA for which those distinctions   # do not apply mcols(gr.promoters) <- mcols(gr.promoters)[,1] colnames(mcols(gr.promoters)) <- "name" ov <- findOverlaps(gr.promoters, mef2c.region) gr.mef2c.promoters <- gr.promoters[queryHits(ov)] track.promoters <- UCSCBedAnnotationTrack("promoters", gr.mef2c.promoters, color="darkGreen") displayTrack(igv, track.promoters)

what: Overlap promoters and variants, create new track
title: Explore VCF variants, GWAS snps, promoters and histone marks around the  MEF2C gene in Alzheimers Disease
text: Non-coding SNPs fall promoter regions plausible candidates examination. may disrupt create transcription factor binding site, thus possibly contribute disease study.
code: gr.variants <- GRanges(tbl.mef2cGWAS.variants.bed) ov <- findOverlaps(gr.variants, gr.promoters) gr.variantsInPromoters <- gr.variants[queryHits(ov)] track.variantsInPromoters <-GRangesAnnotationTrack("snpInPromoters", gr.variantsInPromoters,                                                    color="red", displayMode="EXPANDED") displayTrack(igv, track.variantsInPromoters)

title: Explore VCF variants, GWAS snps, promoters and histone marks around the  MEF2C gene in Alzheimers Disease
text: H3K4me3 histone methylation marks often associated transcription initiation promoter regions. add three tracks AnnotationHub H3K4me3 methylation Gm12878 (lymphoblastoid) cells.
code: histone.tracks <- query(ah.human, c("H3K4me3", "Gm12878", "Peak", "narrow"))  # 3 tracks descriptions <- histone.tracks$description titles <- histone.tracks$title colors <- rep(terrain.colors(6), 4) color.index <- 0  for(i in seq_len(length(histone.tracks))){    name <- names(histone.tracks)[i]    color.index <- color.index + 1    gr <- histone.tracks[[name]]    ov <- findOverlaps(gr, mef2c.region)    mef2c.histones <- gr[queryHits(ov)]    track.histones <- GRangesQuantitativeTrack(titles[i], mef2c.histones[, "pValue"],                                               color=colors[color.index], trackHeight=50,                                               autoscale=TRUE)    displayTrack(igv, track.histones)    } # for track

GWAS variants IGAP (large meta-analysis), promoters RefSeq (conservatively defined), methylation marks lymphoblastoid cell line, WGS variants ADNI. Note also ADNI variants VCF track stratified disease phenotype. Therefore, examining rsid rs80043958 chr5:88,179,576 IGAP GWAS pvalue 0.002, see ADNI heterozygosity 0.269 - information variant displayed popup clicking pinkish “anchor block” - keep mind number informative broken phenotype.

code: loc <- getGenomicRegion(igv) size <- with(loc, 1 + end - start) starts <- seq(loc$start, loc$end, by=5) ends   <- starts + 5 values <- sample(1:100, size=length(starts), replace=TRUE)  tbl.bedGraph <- data.frame(chrom=rep("chr8", length(starts)), start=starts, end=ends,                            value=values, stringsAsFactors=FALSE)  track <- DataFrameQuantitativeTrack("bedGraph", tbl.bedGraph, color="red", autoscale=FALSE,                                     min=80, max=100) displayTrack(igv, track)

title: Explore CTCF ChIP-seq alignments, MACS2 narrowPeaks, Motif Matching and H3K4me3 methylation
text: Transcription factor binding sites often characterized sequence match TF’s curated motif. use motif JASPAR 2022 identify matches hg19 genome region interest.
code: # get the DNA sequence in the current region dna <- with(roi, getSeq(BSgenome.Hsapiens.UCSC.hg19, chrom, start, end))    # get the first of three motifs for CTCF.  (a more thorough study would use all three) pfm.ctcf <- MotifDb::query(MotifDb, c("CTCF", "sapiens", "jaspar2022"), notStrings="ctcfl") motif.name <- names(pfm.ctcf)[1] pfm <- pfm.ctcf[[1]]     # Find matches >= 80% of this motif in the sequence.  create a suitable     # data.frame for another DataFrameQuantitativeTrack  hits.forward <- matchPWM(pfm, as.character(dna), with.score=TRUE, min.score="80%") hits.reverse <- matchPWM(reverseComplement(pfm), as.character(dna), with.score=TRUE, min.score="80%")  tbl.forward <- as.data.frame(ranges(hits.forward)) tbl.reverse <- as.data.frame(ranges(hits.reverse)) tbl.forward$score <- mcols(hits.forward)$score tbl.reverse$score <- mcols(hits.reverse)$score  tbl.matches <- rbind(tbl.forward, tbl.reverse) tbl.matches$chrom <- roi$chrom tbl.matches$start <- tbl.matches$start + roi$start  tbl.matches$end <- tbl.matches$end + roi$start  tbl.matches$name <- paste0("MotifDb::", motif.name) tbl.matches <- tbl.matches[, c("chrom", "start", "end", "name", "score")] dim(tbl.matches) # 25 5 head(tbl.matches)     #   chrom     start       end                                       name    score     # 1  chr3 128110910 128110928 MotifDb::Hsapiens-jaspar2018-CTCF-MA0139.1 10.70369     # 2  chr3 128114573 128114591 MotifDb::Hsapiens-jaspar2018-CTCF-MA0139.1 10.36891     # 3  chr3 128127658 128127676 MotifDb::Hsapiens-jaspar2018-CTCF-MA0139.1 10.44666     # 4  chr3 128138376 128138394 MotifDb::Hsapiens-jaspar2018-CTCF-MA0139.1 10.54861     # 5  chr3 128139280 128139298 MotifDb::Hsapiens-jaspar2018-CTCF-MA0139.1 10.51689     # 6  chr3 128173128 128173146 MotifDb::Hsapiens-jaspar2018-CTCF-MA0139.1 10.37987

what: Render the motif matching in two ways, with two tracks: one for annotation, one for score
title: Explore ChIP-seq alignments from a bam file, MACS2 narrowPeaks, conservation, H3K4me3 methylation and motif matching
text: igvR distinguish annotation tracks, quantitative tracks, tracks (sucs VCF bam). Annotation tracks representation BED format. Quantitative tracks represent WIG format. brief: imagine data.frame five columns: chrom start end name score Construct DataFrameAnnotationTrack columns 1-4. Construct DataFrameQuantitativeTrack columns 1,2,3,5. name (fourth) column contains name MotifDb entry (e.g., “Hsapiens-jaspar2018-CTCF-MA0139.1”) prepend “MotifDb://” support motif logo popup.
code: track <- DataFrameAnnotationTrack("CTCF-MA0139.1", tbl.matches[, 1:4], color="random",                                   trackHeight=25) displayTrack(igv, track)  track <- DataFrameQuantitativeTrack("MA0139.1 scores", tbl.matches[, c(1,2,3,5)],                                      color="random", autoscale=FALSE, min=8, max=12) displayTrack(igv, track)

what: Is there any reason to believe these motif matches are functional?
title: Explore ChIP-seq alignments from a bam file, MACS2 narrowPeaks, conservation, H3K4me3 methylation and motif matching
text: Motifs match DNA sequence great frequency, especially (), relaxed motif matching threshold used. , however, three factors increase likelihood matches identify functional binding sites: found near high-confidence ChIP-seq site DNA sequence highly conserved across species time sequence found known regulatory region associated target gene (GATA2) first factor can see direct inspection browser. second, let’s add phastCons100way genome track, Bioconductor annotation package represents conserved sequence across 100 species millions years. obtain fine-grained assessment conservation, use bins shorter motifs. add conservation track displays conservation every 5-base pair block. Conservation scored 0 1.
code: loc <- getGenomicRegion(igv) starts <- with(loc, seq(start, end, by=5)) ends <- starts + 5 count <- length(starts) tbl.blocks <- data.frame(chrom=rep(loc$chrom, count), start=starts, end=ends, stringsAsFactors=FALSE) dim(tbl.blocks)  tbl.cons100 <- as.data.frame(gscores(phastCons100way.UCSC.hg19, GRanges(tbl.blocks)), stringsAsFactors=FALSE) tbl.cons100$chrom <- as.character(tbl.cons100$seqnames) tbl.cons100 <- tbl.cons100[, c("chrom", "start", "end", "default")] track <- DataFrameQuantitativeTrack("cons100", tbl.cons100, autoscale=TRUE, color="darkgreen") displayTrack(igv, track)

title: Explore ChIP-seq alignments from a bam file, MACS2 narrowPeaks, conservation, H3K4me3 methylation and motif matching
text: H3K4me3 histone methylation marks often associated transcription initiation promoter regions. add three tracks AnnotationHub H3K4me3 methylation Gm12878 (lymphoblastoid) cells.
code: ah <- AnnotationHub() ah.human <- subset(ah, species == "Homo sapiens")  histone.tracks <- AnnotationHub::query(ah.human, c("H3K4me3", "Gm12878", "Peak", "narrow"))  # 3 tracks descriptions <- histone.tracks$description titles <- histone.tracks$title colors <- rep(terrain.colors(6), 4) color.index <- 0  roi <- with(getGenomicRegion(igv), GRanges(seqnames=chrom, IRanges(start=start, end=end)))  for(i in seq_len(length(histone.tracks))){    name <- names(histone.tracks)[i]    color.index <- color.index + 1    gr <- histone.tracks[[name]]    ov <- findOverlaps(gr, roi)    histones <- gr[queryHits(ov)]    track.histones <- GRangesQuantitativeTrack(titles[i], histones[, "pValue"],                                               color=colors[color.index], trackHeight=50,                                               autoscale=TRUE)    displayTrack(igv, track.histones)    Sys.sleep(5)    } # for track showGenomicRegion(igv, "chr3:128,216,201-128,217,324")

text: igvR package provides easy programmatic access R web-based javascript library igv.js. R’s access data, operations upon data, complemented igv’s richly interactive web browser interface display explore genomic epigentic data. vignette present somewhat contrived ChIP-seq study - contrived organized around actual research problem. Instead, vignette demonstrates methods likely use visual QC exploratory data analysis ChIP-seq experiment. begin ENCODE data CTCF binding chromosome 3, hg19 reference genome, vicinity GATA2 gene. display 252 kb region genome load display GenomicAlignments object indexed bam file covering region load display narrow peaks bedGraph track, precalculated MACS2 Use Biostrings::matchPWM method identify regions displayed sequence , least 80% fidelity, match CTCF motif, Jaspar 2018’s MA0138.1, MotifDb Display motif logo browser popup. load sequence conservation data Bioconductor annotation package phastCons100way.UCSC.hg19, looking intersection ChIP peaks, motif match conserved sequence, together suggest locations functional TF binding occurs. two images illustrate final state igv browser conclusion code found . first view spans 35kb: second spans less 1200 bases.

title: Explore ChIP-seq alignments from a bam file, MACS2 narrowPeaks, conservation, H3K4me3 methylation and motif matching

code: library(igvR) library(MotifDb) library(AnnotationHub) library(BSgenome.Hsapiens.UCSC.hg19) library(phastCons100way.UCSC.hg19) igv <- igvR() setBrowserWindowTitle(igv, "CTCF ChIP-seq") setGenome(igv, "hg19") showGenomicRegion(igv, "chr3:128,079,020-128,331,275")

what: Create a GRanges object specifying our region of interest, obtaining a list (chrom, start, end, string) from igv
title: Explore ChIP-seq alignments from a bam file, MACS2 narrowPeaks, conservation, H3K4me3 methylation and motif matching
code: loc <- getGenomicRegion(igv) which <- with(loc, GRanges(seqnames=chrom, ranges = IRanges(start, end))) param <- ScanBamParam(which=which, what = scanBamWhat()) bamFile <- "~/github/ChIPseqMotifMatch/bulk/GSM749704/GSM749704_hg19_wgEncodeUwTfbsGm12878CtcfStdAlnRep1.bam" file.exists(bamFile) x <- readGAlignments(bamFile, use.names=TRUE, param=param) track <- GenomicAlignmentTrack("ctcf bam", x, visibilityWindow=10000000, trackHeight=200)  # 30000 default displayTrack(igv, track)

code: DATADIR=/Users/paul/github/igvR/vignettes/macs2 BAM=GSM749704_hg19_wgEncodeUwTfbsGm12878CtcfStdAlnRep1.bam NAME=GSM749704_hg19_chr19 run:     docker run -v $(DATADIR):/data/ fooliu/macs2 callpeak -t /data/$(BAM) -n $(NAME) --outdir data/ filename <- system.file(package="igvR", "extdata", "GSM749704_hg19_chr19_peaks.narrowPeak") tbl.pk <- get(load(system.file(package="igvR", "extdata", "GSM749704_hg19_chr19_subset.RData"))) track <- DataFrameQuantitativeTrack("macs2 peaks", tbl.pk, color="red", autoscale=TRUE) displayTrack(igv, track)

title: Use a Custom Genome
text: properly configured web server, annotation files, can use igvR genome interest. demonstrate covid-19, SARS-CoV-2 genome, obtained NCBI, hosted nginx webserver running Institute Systems Biology.

title: Use a Custom Genome
text: begin, however, showing explicit configuration required loading hg38 annotated genome hosted igv.org, familiarize full range parameters can use data.
code: library(igvR) igv <- igvR() setBrowserWindowTitle(igv, "hg38 explicit") setCustomGenome(igv,                 id="hg38",                 genomeName="Human (GRCh38/hg38)",                 fastaURL="https://s3.amazonaws.com/igv.broadinstitute.org/genomes/seq/hg38/hg38.fa",                 fastaIndexURL="https://s3.amazonaws.com/igv.broadinstitute.org/genomes/seq/hg38/hg38.fa.fai",                 cytobandURL="https://s3.amazonaws.com/igv.broadinstitute.org/annotations/hg38/cytoBandIdeo.txt",                 chromosomeAliasURL=NA,                 geneAnnotationName="Refseq Genes",                 geneAnnotationURL="https://s3.amazonaws.com/igv.org.genomes/hg38/refGene.txt.gz",                 geneAnnotationTrackHeight=500,                 geneAnnotationTrackColor="darkBlue",                 initialLocus="chr5:88,621,308-89,001,037",                 visibilityWindow=5000000)

title: Use a Custom Genome
code: base.url <- "https://gladki.pl/igvR/testFiles/sarsGenome" fasta.file <- sprintf("%s/%s", base.url,"Sars_cov_2.ASM985889v3.dna.toplevel.fa") fastaIndex.file <-  sprintf("%s/%s", base.url, "Sars_cov_2.ASM985889v3.dna.toplevel.fa.fai") annotation.file <-  sprintf("%s/%s", base.url, "Sars_cov_2.ASM985889v3.101.gff3")  Sys.sleep(2)  setCustomGenome(igv,                 id="Sars_cov_2",                 genomeName="Sars_cov_2.ASM985889v3",                 fastaURL=fasta.file,                 fastaIndexURL=fastaIndex.file,                 geneAnnotationURL=annotation.file,                 geneAnnotationName="ASM985889v3",                 geneAnnotationTrackHeight=500,                 geneAnnotationTrackColor="darkBlue",                 visibilityWindow=30000)

title: Paired-end Interaction Tracks
text: popularity wide availability Hi-C data - high throughput chromatin confirmation capture technology - appropriate display format needed. igv.js team created Interact track, supporint bedpe data file format.

title: Paired-end Interaction Tracks
text: demonstrate track lines extracted Encode project’s ENCFF110BUX experiment, Michael Snyder’s lab, showing boundaries extent two topologically-associated domains (TADS), typically small genomic regions somewhat isolated neighboring regions, believed play role restricting enhancer/promoter interactions. equally important, perhaps common use paired-end interaction data represent Hi-C maps enhancer-promoter interactions. data also rely upon bedpe file format. igv.js provides several visualization parameters yet supported igvR. define TAD, two genomic locations required, shown code :

title: Paired-end Interaction Tracks
text: lines provide complete, minimal introduction BedpeInteractionsTrack.
code: library(igvR) igv <- igvR() setBrowserWindowTitle(igv, "Paired-end demo") setGenome(igv, "hg38") tbl.bedpe <- data.frame(chrom1=c("2","2"),                         start1=c(105780000, 105575000),                         end1=c(105790000, 105600000),                         chrom2=c("2","2"),                         start2=c(105890000, 106075000),                         end2=c(105900000, 106100000),                         stringsAsFactors=FALSE)    # construct a "region of interest" (roi) string from tbl.bedpe   # this is where our two features are found.   shoulder <- 300000 roi <- sprintf("%s:%d-%d", tbl.bedpe$chrom1[1],                            min(tbl.bedpe$start1) - shoulder,                            max(tbl.bedpe$end2) + shoulder)  showGenomicRegion(igv, roi) track <- BedpeInteractionsTrack("ENCFF110BUX", tbl.bedpe) displayTrack(igv, track)

what: Create and display minimal 1-row data.frame centered below MYC on chr8
title: Introduction: a simple demo
code: loc <- getGenomicRegion(igv)  tbl.bed <- data.frame(chrom=loc$chrom, start=loc$start + 2000, end=loc$end-2000,                       name="simple.example", stringsAsFactors=FALSE)  track <- DataFrameAnnotationTrack("simple bed", tbl.bed, color="random") displayTrack(igv, track)

what: Create and display a simulated quantitative (bedGraph) track
title: Introduction: a simple demo
code: loc <- getGenomicRegion(igv) size <- with(loc, 1 + end - start) starts <- seq(loc$start, loc$end, by=5) ends   <- starts + 5 values <- sample(1:100, size=length(starts), replace=TRUE)  tbl.bedGraph <- data.frame(chrom=rep("chr8", length(starts)), start=starts, end=ends,                            value=values, stringsAsFactors=FALSE)  track <- DataFrameQuantitativeTrack("bedGraph", tbl.bedGraph, color="red", autoscale=FALSE,                                     min=80, max=100) displayTrack(igv, track)

what: Zoom out by direct manipulation of the currently displayed region
title: Introduction: a simple demo
code: loc <- getGenomicRegion(igv) half.span <- round((loc$end-loc$start)/2)  new.region <- with(loc, sprintf("%s:%d-%d", chrom, start-half.span, end+half.span)) showGenomicRegion(igv, new.region)

title: Use a Custom Genome
text: properly configured web server, annotation files, can use igvR genome interest. demonstrate covid-19, SARS-CoV-2 genome, obtained NCBI, hosted nginx webserver running Institute Systems Biology.

title: Use a Custom Genome
text: begin, however, showing explicit configuration required loading hg38 annotated genome hosted igv.org, familiarize full range parameters can use data.
code: library(igvR) igv <- igvR() setBrowserWindowTitle(igv, "hg38 explicit") setCustomGenome(igv,                 id="hg38",                 genomeName="Human (GRCh38/hg38)",                 fastaURL="https://s3.amazonaws.com/igv.broadinstitute.org/genomes/seq/hg38/hg38.fa",                 fastaIndexURL="https://s3.amazonaws.com/igv.broadinstitute.org/genomes/seq/hg38/hg38.fa.fai",                 cytobandURL="https://s3.amazonaws.com/igv.broadinstitute.org/annotations/hg38/cytoBandIdeo.txt",                 chromosomeAliasURL=NA,                 geneAnnotationName="Refseq Genes",                 geneAnnotationURL="https://s3.amazonaws.com/igv.org.genomes/hg38/refGene.txt.gz",                 geneAnnotationTrackHeight=500,                 geneAnnotationTrackColor="darkBlue",                 initialLocus="chr5:88,621,308-89,001,037",                 visibilityWindow=5000000)

title: Use a Custom Genome
code: base.url <- "https://gladki.pl/igvR/testFiles/sarsGenome" fasta.file <- sprintf("%s/%s", base.url,"Sars_cov_2.ASM985889v3.dna.toplevel.fa") fastaIndex.file <-  sprintf("%s/%s", base.url, "Sars_cov_2.ASM985889v3.dna.toplevel.fa.fai") annotation.file <-  sprintf("%s/%s", base.url, "Sars_cov_2.ASM985889v3.101.gff3")  Sys.sleep(2)  setCustomGenome(igv,                 id="Sars_cov_2",                 genomeName="Sars_cov_2.ASM985889v3",                 fastaURL=fasta.file,                 fastaIndexURL=fastaIndex.file,                 geneAnnotationURL=annotation.file,                 geneAnnotationName="ASM985889v3",                 geneAnnotationTrackHeight=500,                 geneAnnotationTrackColor="darkBlue",                 visibilityWindow=30000)

        add_header "Vary" "Origin";         add_header 'Access-Control-Allow-Credentials' 'true';         add_header 'Access-Control-Allow-Methods' 'GET, POST, OPTIONS';         add_header 'Access-Control-Allow-Headers' 'DNT,Range,X-CustomHeader,Keep-Alive,User-Agent,X-Requested-With,If-Modified-Since,Cache-Control,Content-Type,Acopenept-Ranges,Content-Encoding,Content-R$         # Tell client that this pre-flight info is valid for 20 days                                                                                                                                                 add_header 'Access-Control-Max-Age' 1728000;         add_header 'Content-Type' 'text/plain charset=UTF-8';         add_header 'Content-Length' 0;         return 204;     }         if ($request_method = 'POST') {         add_header 'Access-Control-Allow-Origin' '*';         add_header 'Access-Control-Allow-Credentials' 'true';         add_header 'Access-Control-Allow-Methods' 'GET, POST, OPTIONS';         add_header 'Access-Control-Allow-Headers' 'DNT,Range,X-CustomHeader,Keep-Alive,User-Agent,X-Requested-With,If-Modified-Since,Cache-Control,Content-Type,Acopenept-Ranges,Content-Encoding,Content-R$         add_header 'Access-Control-Expose-Headers' 'Accept-Ranges,Content-Encoding,Content-Length,Content-Range,Cache-Control,Content-Language,Content-Type,Expires,Last-Modified,Pragma,Date';     }         if ($request_method = 'GET') {         add_header "Access-Control-Allow-Origin" $http_origin;         add_header "Vary" "Origin";         add_header 'Access-Control-Allow-Credentials' 'true';         add_header 'Access-Control-Allow-Methods' 'GET, POST, OPTIONS';         add_header 'Access-Control-Allow-Headers' 'DNT,Range,X-CustomHeader,Keep-Alive,User-Agent,X-Requested-With,If-Modified-Since,Cache-Control,Content-Type,Acopenept-Ranges,Content-Encoding, Content-$         add_header 'Access-Control-Expose-Headers' 'Accept-Ranges,Content-Encoding,Content-Length,Content-Range,Cache-Control,Content-Language,Content-Type,Expires,Last-Modified,Pragma,Date'; title: Explore CTCF ChIP-seq alignments, MACS2 narrowPeaks, Motif Matching and H3K4me3 methylation

title: Explore CTCF ChIP-seq alignments, MACS2 narrowPeaks, Motif Matching and H3K4me3 methylation
text: Transcription factor binding sites often characterized sequence match TF’s curated motif. use motif JASPAR 2022 identify matches hg19 genome region interest.
code: # get the DNA sequence in the current region dna <- with(roi, getSeq(BSgenome.Hsapiens.UCSC.hg19, chrom, start, end))    # get the first of three motifs for CTCF.  (a more thorough study would use all three) pfm.ctcf <- MotifDb::query(MotifDb, c("CTCF", "sapiens", "jaspar2022"), notStrings="ctcfl") motif.name <- names(pfm.ctcf)[1] pfm <- pfm.ctcf[[1]]     # Find matches >= 80% of this motif in the sequence.  create a suitable     # data.frame for another DataFrameQuantitativeTrack  hits.forward <- matchPWM(pfm, as.character(dna), with.score=TRUE, min.score="80%") hits.reverse <- matchPWM(reverseComplement(pfm), as.character(dna), with.score=TRUE, min.score="80%")  tbl.forward <- as.data.frame(ranges(hits.forward)) tbl.reverse <- as.data.frame(ranges(hits.reverse)) tbl.forward$score <- mcols(hits.forward)$score tbl.reverse$score <- mcols(hits.reverse)$score  tbl.matches <- rbind(tbl.forward, tbl.reverse) tbl.matches$chrom <- roi$chrom tbl.matches$start <- tbl.matches$start + roi$start  tbl.matches$end <- tbl.matches$end + roi$start  tbl.matches$name <- paste0("MotifDb::", motif.name) tbl.matches <- tbl.matches[, c("chrom", "start", "end", "name", "score")] dim(tbl.matches) # 25 5 head(tbl.matches)     #   chrom     start       end                                       name    score     # 1  chr3 128110910 128110928 MotifDb::Hsapiens-jaspar2018-CTCF-MA0139.1 10.70369     # 2  chr3 128114573 128114591 MotifDb::Hsapiens-jaspar2018-CTCF-MA0139.1 10.36891     # 3  chr3 128127658 128127676 MotifDb::Hsapiens-jaspar2018-CTCF-MA0139.1 10.44666     # 4  chr3 128138376 128138394 MotifDb::Hsapiens-jaspar2018-CTCF-MA0139.1 10.54861     # 5  chr3 128139280 128139298 MotifDb::Hsapiens-jaspar2018-CTCF-MA0139.1 10.51689     # 6  chr3 128173128 128173146 MotifDb::Hsapiens-jaspar2018-CTCF-MA0139.1 10.37987

text: demonstrate track lines extracted Encode project’s ENCFF110BUX experiment, Michael Snyder’s lab, showing boundaries extent two topologically-associated domains (TADS), typically small genomic regions somewhat isolated neighboring regions, believed play role restricting enhancer/promoter interactions. equally important, perhaps common use paired-end interaction data represent Hi-C maps enhancer-promoter interactions. data also rely upon bedpe file format. igv.js provides several visualization parameters yet supported igvR. define TAD, two genomic locations required, shown code :

title: Paired-end Interaction Tracks
text: lines provide complete, minimal introduction BedpeInteractionsTrack.
code: library(igvR) igv <- igvR() setBrowserWindowTitle(igv, "Paired-end demo") setGenome(igv, "hg38") tbl.bedpe <- data.frame(chrom1=c("2","2"),                         start1=c(105780000, 105575000),                         end1=c(105790000, 105600000),                         chrom2=c("2","2"),                         start2=c(105890000, 106075000),                         end2=c(105900000, 106100000),                         stringsAsFactors=FALSE)    # construct a "region of interest" (roi) string from tbl.bedpe   # this is where our two features are found.   shoulder <- 300000 roi <- sprintf("%s:%d-%d", tbl.bedpe$chrom1[1],                            min(tbl.bedpe$start1) - shoulder,                            max(tbl.bedpe$end2) + shoulder)  showGenomicRegion(igv, roi) track <- BedpeInteractionsTrack("ENCFF110BUX", tbl.bedpe) displayTrack(igv, track)

title: Obtain and Display H3K27ac K562 track from the AnnotationHub
text: broadPeak data GRanges object already memory. Subset obtain 252 kb region interested. igvR’s GrangesQuantitativeTrack must one numeric column GRanges metadata. column used magnitudes track display.
code: roi <- getGenomicRegion(igv) gr.broadpeak <- x.broadPeak[seqnames(x.broadpeak)==roi$chrom &                             start(x.broadpeak) > roi$start &                             end(x.broadpeak) < roi$end] names(mcols(gr.broadpeak))   #  "name"        "score"       "signalValue" "pValue"      "qValue" mcols(gr.broadpeak) <- gr.broadpeak$score track <- GRangesQuantitativeTrack("h3k27ac bp", gr.broadpeak, autoscale=TRUE, color="brown") displayTrack(igv, track)

title: GWAS Tracks
text: Genome Wide Association Studies (GWAS) often viewed “manhattan plot”. igv.js supports thesein two formats: fixed bed format, traditional flexible, multi-column file format GWAS results often summarized. support latter since flexibility can used five-column fixed bed format well. data GWAS studies rather sparse, usually hundred variant hotspots associate phenotype interest. Another feature data community often concerned statistical significance association. expressed pvalue. minus-log10 transform pvalue controls height rendered variant manhattant plot. Support track type igvR new (summer 2022) unpolished. Control autoscaling fixed scaling needs work. two relevant classes, shown constructors: GWASTrack(“bellenguuez”, tbl.gwas, chrom.col=1, pos.col=2, pval.col=5, trackHeight=80) GWASUrlTrack(“igv sample”, url, chrom.col=12, pos.col=13, pval.col=28) arguments , except second one, either local data.frame memory, url pointing remote file served http.

title: GWAS Tracks
text: use 5-column data.frame file hosted igvR’s extdata, GWAS results 2022 Nature Genetics paper, New insights genetic etiology Alzheimer’s disease related dementias. first rows:  Zoomed neighborhood TREM2, gene independently known associated Alzheimer’s Disease.
code: chrom     start       end        name    score 1  chr1 109345809 109345810 rs141749679 2.36e-04 2  chr1 207577222 207577223    rs679515 1.51e-14 3  chr2   9558881   9558882  rs72777026 4.14e-03 4  chr2  37304795  37304796  rs17020490 2.33e-04 5  chr2 105749598 105749599 rs143080277 6.29e-04 6  chr2 127135233 127135234   rs6733839 2.06e-30 library(igvR) igv <- igvR() setBrowserWindowTitle(igv, "AD GWAS") setGenome(igv, "hg38") tbl.gwas <- read.table(system.file(package="igvR", "extdata", "gwas", "bellenguez.bed"),                        sep="\t", as.is=TRUE, header=TRUE, nrow=-1) track <- GWASTrack("bellenguuez", tbl.gwas, chrom.col=1, pos.col=2, pval.col=5, trackHeight=80) displayTrack(igv, track)

title: igvR: integrative genomics viewer
text: igvR R package providing interactive connections igv.js (Integrative Genomics Viewer) running web browser. grateful Jim Robinson, Helga Thorvaldsdóttir, Douglass Turner colleagues fine work igv.js, unfailing responsiveness requests questions. igvR based upon Bioconductor R package BrowserViz - subclass. offers easy interactive visual exploration genomic data R, including Bed (annotation) BedGraph (quantitative) tracks can created R data.frames GenomicRanges objects. Aligment data bam files via GAlignments objects offered GenomicAlignments class variant data VCF files via VCF objects offered VariantAnnotation class. GWAS tabular data genomic coordinates bed-like format work motivated belief contemporary web browsers, supporting HTML5 Canvas, running increasingly powerful Javascript libraries (Three.js, d3, igv.js cytoscape.js) become best setting develop interactive graphics exploratory data analysis. package first cousin, igvShiny. RStudio may point release version Shiny , launched, leaves R console open interactive commands. feature available, merge igvR igvShiny. package fully documented , full function reference many examples vignettes (see Articles menu).

text: trackName character string, used track label igv, recommend unique names per track. table data.frame 6 columns color css color name (e.g., "red" "#FF0000" trackHeight track height, typically range 20 (annotations) 1000 (large sample vcf files) displayMode "COLLAPSED", "SQUISHED" "EXPANDED". code: #----------------------------     #  first, from a local file     #----------------------------    file <- system.file(package="igvR", "extdata", "sixColumn-demo1.bedpe")   tbl.bedpe <- read.table(file, sep="\t", as.is=TRUE, header=TRUE)   dim(tbl.bedpe)  #  32 6 #> [1] 32  6   track <- BedpeInteractionsTrack("bedpe-6", tbl.bedpe)      #------------------------------------------     #  show the relevant portion of the genome     #------------------------------------------    shoulder <- 10000   roi <- with(tbl.bedpe, sprintf("%s:%d-%d", chrom1[1], min(start1)-shoulder, max(end2) + shoulder))   # showGenomicRegion(igv, roi)    # displayTrack(igv, track)

code: tbl.gff3 <- read.table(system.file(package="igvR", "extdata", "GRCh38.94.NDUFS2.gff3"),                        sep="\t", as.is=TRUE) colnames(tbl.gff3) <- c("seqid", "source", "type", "start", "end", "score", "strand",                         "phase", "attributes") colors <- list("antisense" = "blueviolet",                "protein_coding" = "blue",                "retained_intron" = "rgb(0, 150, 150)",                "processed_transcript" = "purple",                "processed_pseudogene" = "#7fff00",                "unprocessed_pseudogene" = "#d2691e",                "default" = "black")  track <- GFF3Track("dataframe gff3", tbl.gff3, colorByAttribute="biotype", colorTable=colors,                    url=NA_character_, indexURL=NA_character_, displayMode="EXPANDED", trackHeight=200,                    visibilityWindow=100000)

title: Constructor for VariantTrack — VariantTrack-class
code: #----------------------------     #  first, from a local file     #----------------------------  f <- system.file("extdata", "chr22.vcf.gz", package="VariantAnnotation") roi <- GRanges(seqnames="22", ranges=IRanges(start=c(50301422, 50989541),                                               end=c(50312106, 51001328),                                               names=c("gene_79087", "gene_644186"))) vcf.sub <- VariantAnnotation::readVcf(f, "hg19", param=roi) track.local <- VariantTrack("chr22-tiny", vcf.sub)      #----------------------------     # now try a url track     #----------------------------  data.url <- sprintf("%s/%s", "https://s3.amazonaws.com/1000genomes/release/20130502",                                "ALL.wgs.phase3_shapeit2_mvncall_integrated_v5b.20130502.sites.vcf.gz") index.url <- sprintf("%s.tbi", data.url) url <- list(data=data.url, index=index.url)  track.url <- VariantTrack("1kg", url)

display the specified track in igv — displayTrack,igvR-method
code: if(interactive()){    igv <- igvR()    setGenome(igv, "hg38")    showGenomicRegion(igv, "MEF2C")    base.loc <- 88883100    tbl <- data.frame(chrom=rep("chr5", 3),                      start=c(base.loc, base.loc+100, base.loc + 250),                      end=c(base.loc + 50, base.loc+120, base.loc+290),                      name=c("a", "b", "c"),                      score=runif(3),                      strand=rep("*", 3),                      stringsAsFactors=FALSE)    track <- DataFrameAnnotationTrack("dataframeTest", tbl, color="red",                                       displayMode="EXPANDED")    displayTrack(igv, track)    }

what: turn mottif log popups on or off — enableMotifLogoPopups,igvR-method
title: turn mottif log popups on or off — enableMotifLogoPopups,igvR-method
text: tracks represent transcription factor binding sites, traditionally represented motif logo.  use method enable capability - depends upon properly constructed tbl.regions data.frame DataFrameAnnotationTrack: addition usual (mandatory) chrom, start, end columns.  enable track-click popups  binding site, tbl.regions data.frame must also "name" column, format, example:    "MotifDb::Hsapiens-HOCOMOCOv10-MEF2C_HUMAN.H10MO.C" first part name, "MotifDb::", tells igv want view specified MotifDb pwm (motif logo, matrix) binding site track element clicked. Limitations:  method works call setGenome(igv, "genome interest").               works DataFrameAnnotationTrack objects (now)

code: if(interactive()){    igv <- igvR(title="igv demo")    setGenome(igv, "hg38")    showGenomicRegion(igv, "MEF2C")      #---------------------------------------------------------------      # an easy transparent way to create a bed track      #---------------------------------------------------------------    base.loc <- 88883100    tbl <- data.frame(chrom=rep("chr5", 3),                      start=c(base.loc, base.loc+100, base.loc + 250),                      end=c(base.loc + 50, base.loc+120, base.loc+290),                      name=c("a", "b", "c"),                      score=runif(3),                      strand=rep("*", 3),                      stringsAsFactors=FALSE)     track <- DataFrameAnnotationTrack("dataframeTest", tbl, color="red", displayMode="EXPANDED")    displayTrack(igv, track)    showGenomicRegion(igv, sprintf("chr5:%d-%d", base.loc-100, base.loc+350))    } # if interactive

code: if(interactive()){    igv <- igvR()    setGenome(igv, "hg19")    showGenomicRegion(igv, "MEF2C")      # create three arbitrary tracks    base.loc <- 88883100    tbl <- data.frame(chrom=rep("chr5", 3),                      start=c(base.loc, base.loc+100, base.loc + 250),                      end=c(base.loc + 50, base.loc+120, base.loc+290),                      name=c("a", "b", "c"),                      score=runif(3),                      strand=rep("*", 3),                      stringsAsFactors=FALSE)    track.1 <- DataFrameAnnotationTrack("track.1", tbl, color="red", displayMode="SQUISHED")    track.2 <- DataFrameAnnotationTrack("track.2", tbl, color="blue", displayMode="SQUISHED")    track.3 <- DataFrameAnnotationTrack("track.3", tbl, color="green", displayMode="SQUISHED")    displayTrack(igv, track.1)    displayTrack(igv, track.2)    displayTrack(igv, track.3)    removeTracksByName(igv, "track.2")      #----------------------------------------      # bulk removal of the remaining tracks,      # but leave the h19 reference track      #----------------------------------------    removeTracksByName(igv, getTrackNames(igv)[-1])    }
